No, aggregators won't fix this. Marketplaces hate aggregators as they: 
1) get between them and their customers (so no customer data);
2) add friction and take fees; and 
3) potentially disintermediate the market by internalizing orders (or building a competitor) https://t.co/6pNXW6317T

@LooksRareNFT not pushing back on you or any of the other NFT marketplaces that have launched or are launching. i'm completely indifferent as to who wins
good luck. i hope you kick ass!

@alwaysjoshua competition (and decentralization) is fantastic. but in markets, fragmentation is bad for liquidity and price discovery...especially for something one of a kind, like NFTs. and no, we do not have a stake in opensea
PSA: The fragmentation of the NFT secondary market away from OpenSea will be terrible for the NFT market (and prices)

@alexsunnarborg ETH value will rise and fall based on many factors. MANA will only rise if DCL is successful. and of course, all of this is predicated on MANA being a utility token and not a security (which was our analysis conclusion)

@alexsunnarborg as an extreme example, Samsung could buy $xx mm of MANA and then give away VR goggles with a MANA wallet built in. IF DCL is successful, they could make more money on the MANA than they could on selling the goggles 4/

@alexsunnarborg and by having an in world currency, there is an opportunity for new business models to emerge that reward content creators, service providers, etc. to benefit from the value increase of MANA 3/
@alexsunnarborg and this provides an opportunity for investors to "bet" on Decentraland without owning land 2/

@alexsunnarborg thoughtful analysis (like usual). but worth taking into account that new land that gets sold as DCL expands must get purchased via MANA (which then gets burned), thereby decreasing the MANA supply as the land mass grows 1/

7/All in all, the BitLicense is bad for bitcoin, the community and NY...but creates real competitive advantage for those with a license.
6/For banks, brokerages, etc. looking to get into the bitcoin market making business, they will look to acquire companies with a license
5/In my opinion, the application and process will only get longer, which creates an even deeper moat
4/The application backlog is unknown, as is application period, so the DFS has just given a very unfair advantage to companies that applied
3/Effective immediately, a bitcoin exchange business looking to start doing business in NY state will need to wait for NYDFS approval
2/The new BitLicense has unintentionally created a deep moat around the more mature, well capitalized bitcoin exchanges
1/Some thoughts on the new NYDFS BitLicense that went into effect this past Friday...
